dcterms:title: Increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers
dcterms:abstract: Bloom syndrome (BSyn, OMIM #210900) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. Recent studies have identified increased risk of cancers in BLM PV carriers. Using exome sequencing of BSyn patients and BLM carriers, researchers found that both BSyn probands and BLM carriers exhibited an increased frequency of CHIP compared to sex- and age-matched controls. This study sheds new light on the interplay between genetic predispositions and somatic variation and highlights the need for additional studies to further evaluate the mechanisms and potential clinical implications for patients with one or two BLM PV.

dcterms:hasPart: A research paper published in Haematologica volume 110 page 187 in January 2025 investigates Bloom syndrome and clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential CHIP Bloom syndrome BSyn OMIM 210900 is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction sun sensitivity insulin resistance mild immune deficiency and increased risk of early onset malignancy The study found increased cancer risks in BLM PV carriers Through exome sequencing of BSyn patients and BLM carriers researchers discovered both groups showed higher CHIP frequency compared to matched controls The research utilized 29 peripheral blood DNA samples including ten BSyn probands and their biological parents The methodology employed several key instruments including Illumina NovaSeq S1 for sequencing with 2x150 flowcell Nextera DNA Flex Pre Enrichment Library Prep for library preparation and Roche NimbleGen exome capture kit The analysis protocol followed GATK best practices pipeline for quality control mapping and variant calling with specific parameters for variant allele frequency analysis VAF less than 03 for somatic variants and VAF greater than or equal to 03 for germline variants All study participants provided informed consent under a protocol approved by the Weill Cornell Medical College Institutional Review Board This research contributes to understanding the relationship between genetic predispositions and somatic variation emphasizing the importance of further studies to evaluate mechanisms and potential clinical implications for patients with one or two BLM PV The findings illuminate the complex interplay between inherited genetic variants and acquired somatic mutations in the context of blood disorders and cancer predisposition
